questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of dorsal mesogastrium except
questions.solution:
• The abdominal part of the foregut is suspended by mesenteries both ventrally and dorsally.
  • The ventral mesentery of the foregut is called the ventral mesogastrium, and the dorsal mesentery is called dorsal mesogastrium (gastrium means stomach)
  • The fate of ventral mesogastrium(pneumonic - Lesser FACT)

    • FAlciform ligament
    • Coronary ligament
    • Triangular ligament
  • The fate of the dorsal mesogastrium is as follows.
    • Gastrosplenic ligament
    • Lineorenal ligament
    • Gastrophrenic ligament
    • Greater omentum

Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C: are derivatives of dorsal mesogastrium.

Option D: Falciform ligament is derivative of ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contraindicate a neuraxial block?
questions.solution:
Patient on antihypertensive medication is not a contraindication for neuraxial block.

Absolute contraindications:

  • Patient's refusal
  • Patient's inability to maintain stillness during the needle puncture (can be seen in case of dementia, psychosis)
  • Raised intracranial tension
  • Severe stenotic valvular heart disease
  • Marked skin sepsis
  • Marked spinal deformity
  • Marked coagulopathy, blood dyscrasias or full anticoagulant therapy

Relative contraindications:

  • Pre-existing neurological deficit (demyelinating lesions) due to medicolegal problems
  • All severe and marked diseases present in lesser degree (spinal deformity, sepsis)
  • Pre-eclamptic toxemia
  • Mildly impaired coagulation
  • Patients with platelet < 80,000/ml

By looking at the lines at the neck of the image and by the pattern in the shape of "V" we can conclude that the image is the diagram of Lines of Langer.

Lines of Langer are the relaxed tension lines. They represent the orientation of collagen fibers. They look like an egyptian mummy or a v shaped necklace on the body.

questions.text: Delirium tremens is seen in:
questions.solution:
DELIRIUM TREMENS

This is an acute organic brain syndrome, usually seen within 3-4 days of complete absence from heavy alcohol drinking in chronic alcoholics, and most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome.

It is said to result from cerebral edema and increased csf pressure

Causes

  • Sudden excess or sudden withdrawal of alcohol.
  • Long continual ingestion of alcohol.
  • Shock due to severe trauma, e.g., fracture of long bones.
  • Acute infections, like pneumonia or influenza ,erysipelas etc.
  • exposure to cold

Signs and Symptoms

There is an acute attack of mental illness in which there is:

  1. Clouding of consciousness with disorientation in time and space.
  2. Coarse muscular tremors of face, tongue and hands.
  3. Insomnia with reversal of sleep-wake cycle, and loss of memory.
  4. Psychomotor agitation, ataxia, uncontrollable fear, and tendency to commit suicide/homicide/violent assault or cause damage to property.
  5. Marked autonomic disturbances with tachycardia, fever, sweating, hypertension and pupillary dilatation.
  6. Peculiar type of delirium of horrors due to hallucinations of sight and hearing. Tactile hallucinations of insects and ants crawling under the skin or on the beds may occur.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man develops swallowing difficulties and complains of difficulty walking up stairs since past 6 months. On examination, there is weakness and wasting of the distal muscles of the arms. There are visible fasciculations. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk and the plantars are up going. There are no sensory abnormalities. Speech and language assessment suggests the presence of pharyngeal muscle weakness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pure motor weakness, with UMN features like hyper-reflexia and extensor plantar and LMN features like fasciculations.

  • This is a classical presentation of motor neuron disease.
  • There is a pseudobulbar palsy in association with fasciculations of the muscles and a mixture of upper and lower motor neuron signs.
  • GBS is less likely as it is not acute onset, no preceding infection.
  • Moreover, fasciculation and muscle wasting are the classic features found in MND and not in GBS. This features also differentiates it from Myasthenia gravis.
  • As sensory is normal, CIDP is less likely.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presents with a chronic skin rash and painful, red nodules on the extremities. The rash has been present for several months and is not responding to standard antifungal treatments. A biopsy of the skin lesions shows yeast cells with pseudohyphae. An image of the skin biopsy shows characteristic findings of Candida infection.
Identify the phenomenon shown in the image that is associated with Candida infection.
questions.solution:
• REYNOLD BRAUDE phenomenon/Germ tube test is shown by candida albicans, candida dubliniensis when candida is grown with growth factors.
  • Forms chlamydospores in corn meal agar
  • Cells in a line - pseudohyphae
  • On SDA - Creamy/pasty/yeasty colonies.
  • CHROMAGAR - Used to differentiate different kinds of candida

Explanation:

  • A) Reynold braude Phenomenon: This phenomenon is specifically associated with Candida infections, characterized by the formation of germ tube when candida is allowed to grow on media containing growth factors.
  • B) Koebner Phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the appearance of isomorphic skin lesions at sites of trauma in conditions like psoriasis, not typically seen in Candida infections.
  • C) Nikolsky Sign: This sign is associated with conditions like pemphigus vulgaris and involves skin detachment with slight pressure, not relevant to Candida infections.
  • D) Auspitz Sign: This sign is observed in psoriasis, where small bleeding points are seen when scales are removed from the plaques, not related to Candida infections.

Key Takeaway: Reynold braude Phenomenon: This phenomenon is specifically associated with Candida infections, characterized by the formation of germ tube when candida is allowed to grow on media containing growth factors

questions.text:
A patient met with RTA and developed knee pain with hemarthrosis. An MRI of the knee joint was done after 1 week which showed injury to posterior cruciate ligament and postero-lateral corner of the knee joint. Which clinical tests will be positive in this patient?
1. DIAL test
2. Lachman test
3. Posterior drawer test
4. McMurray's test
questions.solution:
Dial Test

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnose posterolateral knee injury.
    • Differentiate between:
      • Isolated Posterolateral Corner (PLC) injury.
      • Combination of PLC and Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) injury.
  • Tibial External Rotation (Dial) Test:
    • Procedure:
      • Assess external rotation of the tibia on the femur at both 30 and 90 degrees of knee flexion.
      • The test can be performed with the patient either supine or prone.
    • Findings:
      • Isolated PLC Injury:
        • More than a 10-degree increase in external rotation compared to the contralateral side at 30 degrees of knee flexion, but not at 90 degrees.
      • PLC and PCL Injury:
        • Pathologic external rotation at 30 degrees of knee flexion.
        • Increased external rotation when the knee is flexed to 90 degrees.
  • For Isolated PCL Tear:
    • The posterior drawer test or sag test are more relevant.

(Option A and C) - In this case both PCL and PLC are injured, hence both posterior drawer and DIAL test will be positive.

(Option B) - Lachman's test is most sensitive test for ACL injury.

(Option D) - McMurray's test is user for clinical examination in meniscus injuries.

questions.text: Key features of kangaroo mother care are all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Kangaroo care is a technique practiced on newborn, usually preterm, infants wherein the infant is held, skin to-skin, with an adult.
  • The kangaroo position provides ready access to nourishment.
  • The parent's stable body temperature helps to regulate the neonate's temperature more smoothly than an incubator, and allows for readily accessible breastfeeding.
  • Babies who are eligible for kangaroo care include pre term infants, weighing less than 1,500 grams, and breathing independently.
  • Cardiopulmonary monitoring, oximetry, supplemental oxygen or nasal (continuous positive airway pressure) ventilation, intravenous infusion, and monitor leads do not prevent kangaroo care.
  • Babies who are in kangaroo care tend to be less prone to apnea and bradycardia and have stabilization of oxygen needs.
  • KMC provider can involve father or other relatives of baby other than mother.

questions.text: A 18 year old boy was brought to emergency room after consuming some unknown substance from his farm itself. On arrival to emergency room he was sweating, salivating and lacrimating. The boy also had involuntary urination and diarrhea. On examination by the attending consultant, his heart rates were 64 beats per minute and his blood pressure was 78/58 mm Hg. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical features are suggestive of Organophosphate(Anticholinesterase) poisoning.

ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING

Clinical features:

Treatment

  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes-

(a) Atropine: It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

  • It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.
  • All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinisation appear

Option B: N-acetylcysteine used for paracetamol poisoning

Option C: Naloxone is helpful in opioids poisoning

Option D: Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is occasionally used in atropine or scopolamine poisoning.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient went to emergency dept with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, his respiratory rate is 30/min. An ECG is performed, which shows significant ST-segment changes in lead aVf (intense negative injury potential changes). Which of the following area of heart shows ischemic changes?
questions.solution:
• AVf lead connects the positive electrode to the left foot. It gives recording about inferior surface of the heart.
  • Option d: The intense injury potential in chest lead aVf having strong negative injury potential during the T-P interval is found, which means that the chest electrode over the left foot is in an area of strongly negative potential.
  • This means that the current of injury is emanating from the inferior wall of the ventricles, which diagnoses this condition as an inferior wall infarction.
  • Option b: In anterior wall MI lead V1 and V2 shows ST changes.
  • Option c: In posterior wall MI in lead I and aVL strong positive potential is seen due to current of injury.
  • Option a: Prominent Q wave is seen in respective leads according to the table

questions.text: All of the following are indications of anticholinergics as a premedication except?
questions.solution:
The correct option is C: Sedation and amnesia.

  • Anticholinergics, such as glycopyrrolate or atropine, are commonly used as premedication to provide certain beneficial effects during anesthesia.
  • Indications for anticholinergics include drying of airway secretions, prevention of bradycardia, and prevention of gastric aspiration.
  • Some anticholinergic drugs like Scopolamine have mild sedative and amnestic effects, but most anticholinergics do not typically cause sedation or amnesia.

questions.text:
An 18 year-old female is admitted with a depression of her conscious level. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed:

pH 7.26
pO2 90 mmHg
pC02 29.25 mmHg
standard bicarbonate 14.7 mmol/L

Which one of the following would account for these results?
questions.solution:
The provided arterial blood gas results show:

  • pH 7.26 (lower than the normal range of 7.35-7.45)
  • pO2 90 mmHg (within the normal range)
  • paCO2 29.25 mmHg (decreased)
  • HCO3 14.7 mmhg(decreased)
  • Standard bicarbonate 14.7 mmol/L (lower than the normal range)

These results suggest a primary metabolic acidosis. The low pH and low standard bicarbonate are indicative of an acidotic state. The decreased PaCO2 indicates that there may be partial respiratory compensation occurring, which is the body's attempt to raise the pH by letting out carbon dioxide (which is acidic when dissolved in the blood).

So, the correct answer is:

B) Metabolic acidosis This is a physiological condition characterized by a decrease in blood pH due to an accumulation of acid or a loss of bicarbonate. In this case, the low standard bicarbonate indicates a loss of bicarbonate, contributing to the acidosis.

The underlying cause of the metabolic acidosis would need further investigation, but it's not due to analytical error, respiratory acidosis, or persistent vomiting based on the information provided.

questions.text: Blue lines are not seen in poisoning by
questions.solution:
Blue lines are not seen in Arsenic poisoning.

Burton's or Burtonian line:

Morphology:

  • A stippled blue line (or bluish black) is seen on gums in 50-70% cases of chronic lead poisoning (Plumbism/saturnism).

Characteristics:

  • More common in upper jaw
  • Appears within a week of exposure
  • Not seen in edentulous persons
  • Removal from exposure obliterates line gradually
  • More common in persons with bad prenatal hygiene, carious teeth

Mechanism:

  • Subepithelial deposition of black Pb granules
  • Bad oral hygiene-food sticking in gums decomposition → H2S formed → Reacts with Pb in tissues forms PbS [black]

Differential diagnosis:

  • Similar lines seen in poisoning by bismuth, copper, iron, mercury and silver (due to formation of sulphides of each). In copper poisoning, it is green in colour, known as Clapton's lines

questions.text:
A patient with chronic pulmonary symptoms and a history of working outdoors presents for evaluation. The biopsy image shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

What fungal infection does the biopsy most likely suggest?
questions.solution:
Also known as Gilchrist/North American blastomycosis.

Dimorphic Nature: Blastomyces exists in two forms:

  • Mold forms in the environment (25°C).
  • Yeast forms in human tissues (37°C), which is the pathogenic form.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Pulmonary Blastomycosis: Cough, fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing, often resembling pneumonia.
  • Disseminated Disease: In severe cases, it spreads to the skin, bones, joints, and central nervous system.

A) Blastomycosis: Characterized by broad-based budding yeast cells, indicative of Blastomyces dermatitidis.

B) Sporotrichosis: Shows cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae.

C) Candidiasis: Displays yeast cells with pseudohyphae.

D) Aspergillosis: Features septate hyphae with acute-angle branching.

Key Takeaway: Blastomycosis is identified by broad-based budding yeast cells, particularly in patients with relevant occupational or environmental exposure.

choices.text: Trochlear nerve palsy (4th cranial nerve) - Characterized by difficulty with downward and inward eye movements, leading to vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when the patient looks downward
Ocular motor nerve palsy (3rd cranial nerve) - Typically presents with ptosis, diplopia, and an eye that is positioned down and out
Abducent nerve palsy (6th cranial nerve) - Characterized by an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to horizontal diplopia
Optic nerve palsy (2nd cranial nerve) - Primarily affects vision and not ocular motility, leading to vision loss rather than diplopia

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with diplopia, particularly when looking downwards, and a noticeable head tilt to the right. Upon examination, the patient exhibits difficulty in adduction of the left eye and the left eye shows an inability to move downward. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
4th Cranial Nerve Palsy (Trochlear Nerve Palsy):

  • Function of the Trochlear Nerve: Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which controls downward and inward eye movements.
  • Symptoms:
    • Diplopia (Double Vision): Particularly noticeable when looking down or reading.
    • Difficulty with Downward Gaze: The affected eye may drift upward (hyperopia) and may not move downwards properly.
    • Head Tilt: Patients often tilt their head away from the affected side to compensate for the misalignment and reduce diplopia.
  • Common Causes:
    • Idiopathic: Many cases have no identifiable cause.
    • Trauma: Head injuries can damage the nerve.
    • Vascular Conditions: Such as hypertension or diabetes.
    • Tumors: Space-occupying lesions that affect the nerve's pathway.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Observing the eye movements, head posture, and symptoms.
  • Imaging: MRI or CT scans may be used to identify underlying causes or confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Observation: Mild cases may resolve spontaneously.
  • Prisms: Glasses with prisms can help manage diplopia.
  • Surgery: In persistent cases, surgical intervention may be considered to correct the misalignment.

Option B) Ocular motor nerve palsy (3rd cranial nerve) presents with ptosis, diplopia, and an eye that is deviated down and out, not specifically with difficulty in downward gaze alone.

Option C) Abducent nerve palsy (6th cranial nerve) involves difficulty with lateral movement of the eye and horizontal diplopia, not with vertical movements.

Option D) Optic nerve palsy (2nd cranial nerve) primarily affects vision and does not cause ocular motility problems or diplopia

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Trochlear nerve palsy is characterized by difficulty moving the eye downward, especially noticeable when the patient attempts to look down or read. It often results in vertical diplopia and compensatory head tilt.

choices.text: Thomas splint for applying skeletal traction
Bohler-Braun splint for applying skin traction
Bohler-Braun splint for applying skeletal traction
Cramer wire splint for splinting and transportation

questions.text: Identify the splint and choose correct option according to its indication:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Bohler-Brown splint.

Skeletal traction is used for fracture shaft of femur and intertrochanteric fractures.

Bohler-Braun splint: It has a number of pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving skeletal traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of countertraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Option A -: It is one of the commonest splints used in orthopaedic practice. It was devised by H.O. Thomas, initially for immobilisation for tuberculosis of the knee. It is now commonly used for the immobilisation and transportation of hip and thigh injuries.

Fig. Thomas splint

Option D - Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splintage of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes in order to immobilise different parts of the body.

Fig. Cramer splint

questions.text: A 75 years old male patient presented to the urology department with complaints of dribbling of urine with urgency and increased frequency of micturition. He was started on prazosin therapy but the patient later developed complaints of postural hypotension. Which of the following is the better alternative drug for this patient to avoid postural hypotension without compromising clinical benefit?
questions.solution:
• Tamsulosin
  • This relatively uroselective α1A/α1D blocker (α1A : α1B affinity 7-38 fold)
  • It has been found as effective as terazosin in improving BHP symptoms, because α1A subtypes predominate in the bladder base and prostate.
  • However, it lacks the prostatic apoptosis promoting property of terazosin and doxazosin.
  • Tamsulosin does not cause significant changes in BP or HR at doses which relieve urinary symptoms, and it is not used as an antihypertensive.
  • No increase in adverse cardiovascular events has been noted after prolonged use.
  • Postural hypotension is infrequent, dizziness and retrograde ejaculation are the only significant side effects.
  • The problem of floppy iris has been encountered during cataract surgery in patients taking tamsulosin.

Options B,C,D are non selective alpha 1 receptor blockers and hence can cause postural hypotension as a side effect.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient has undergone the heart transplant procedure due to progressive heart failure. After transplant the cardiac responses are recorded in the patient to moderate exercise. Which of the following parameters does not change in the patient with exercise compared to normal.?
questions.solution:
• A transplanted heart is denervated. It does not have neural input. It depends primarily on the increase in stroke volume with exercise.
  • Physiological Comparison of Normal Heart and Transplanted Heart
  • Option c: The heart rate does not change in response to exercise as it is increased by sympathetic stimulation.
  • Option d: The heterometric regulation or intrinsic regulation according to the frank sterling's law the stroke volume increases due to increase in venous return and end diastolic volume of blood. Thus, it increases the stroke volume.
  • Option b: Cardiac output is equal to stroke volume multiplied by heart rate. As the stroke volume increases the output increases even though heart rate does not change.
  • Option a: With moderate exercise the need for oxygen increases. It is fulfilled by an increase in respiratory activity to fulfill the required amount of oxygen.

• The symptoms and findings clearly point out towards pulmonary embolism (PE). As the clinical probability of PE is high, measurement of D-dimer should not be performed, since the result would not alter the need for definitive investigation.

questions.text: Which is an exception to mandatory steps of Traditional Rapid Sequence induction?
questions.solution:
• Traditional Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) is a technique used to rapidly induce anesthesia while minimizing the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.
  • Order: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.

Steps of RAPID SEQUENCE INDUCTION:

  1. Preoxygenation with 100% O2
  2. Administration of Rapid acting IV induction agent (Thiopentone, Propofol)
  3. Sellick's Maneuver (cricoid pressure) by assistant
  4. IV Succinyl-choline 45 sec
  5. Do NOT ventilate patient
  6. Direct laryngoscopy and intubation
  7. Confirm ETT placement
  8. Remove cricoid pressure

questions.text: St. Anthony's fire characterized by burning pain is due to:
questions.solution:
Ergot is the dried sclerotium of the fungus Claviceps purpurea which grows on stale grains, particularly rye, barley, maize and wheat.

Fatal dose: 1-2 g.

Fatal period: Few days.

Chronic poisoning (ergotism) may either be convulsive or gangrenous in type.

  • In convulsive type, there is twitching, tingling, numbness and pain in the muscles. There may be headache, drowsiness, giddiness, formication and convulsions.
  • In gangrenous type, which resembles ;Raynaud's disease, there is a burning pain (called St. Anthony's fire) in the limbs with alternating heat and cold sense, numbness and tingling or anaesthesia. "In fingers, toes, ears, nose, hands and feet, there may be dry gangrene without swelling and ulceration.

questions.text: Examine the image of the electron microscope view provided. Which virus is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• Shape:
    • Typically spherical or oval, with a diameter of about 80-120 nm.
    • Some strains can be pleomorphic, meaning they may vary in shape, occasionally forming filamentous structures.
  • Envelope:
    • The virus is enveloped, meaning it has a lipid membrane derived from the host cell.
    • Embedded in the envelope are two key surface proteins:
      • Hemagglutinin (HA): Responsible for binding to host cell receptors.
      • Neuraminidase (NA): Helps the virus to release from the host cell after replication.
  • Core:
    • Inside the envelope is the viral genome, made up of 8 segments of single-stranded RNA, which are associated with nucleoproteins and packaged in a helical configuration.
  • Surface:
    • The surface of the virus is studded with the HA and NA spikes, which give the virus its characteristic appearance and are crucial for its infectivity.

A) HIV: HIV particles are spherical but have a more irregular shape and are covered with a dense layer of glycoprotein spikes, which is different from the spiked structure seen in the image.

B) Influenza Virus: Influenza virus particles are spherical with a lipid envelope and characteristic spikes (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase), fitting the description of the image.

C) HBV: Hepatitis B virus is more spherical with a less pronounced spiked appearance and has a more complex surface structure.

D) HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus is known for its icosahedral capsid structure and does not typically exhibit the spiked envelope seen in the image.

Key Takeaway: The Influenza Virus is characterized by its spherical shape with a spiked envelope. Identifying these spikes helps in distinguishing it from other viruses.

Reference: For more information on the Influenza Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Influenza (Flu).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe headache, proptosis of the left eye, diplopia, and decreased vision in the same eye. On examination, there is evidence of left cranial nerve VI palsy and facial numbness on the left side. The patient has a history of recurrent sinus infections. A CT scan reveals an abnormality in the cavernous sinus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis

  • Definition: A serious condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot within the cavernous sinus, a cavity at the base of the skull through which cranial nerves and the internal carotid artery pass.
  • Causes:
    • Infections: The most common cause, often originating from the face or sinuses, such as in cases of sinusitis or facial cellulitis.
    • Trauma: Head injuries can lead to thrombosis.
    • Hypercoagulable States: Conditions that increase the risk of clot formation.

Symptoms:

  • Ocular Symptoms:
    • Proptosis: Bulging of the eye.
    • Diplopia (Double Vision): Due to involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Decreased Vision: Often resulting from involvement of the optic nerve.
  • Neurological Symptoms:
    • Headache: Severe and persistent.
    • Facial Pain or Numbness: Due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Abducens Nerve Palsy: Difficulty moving the eye outward.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Assessment of ocular and neurological signs.
  • Imaging:
    • MRI or CT Scan: Used to visualize the cavernous sinus and detect thrombosis.

CECT brain - empty delta sign suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis

Treatment:

  • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat underlying infections.
  • Anticoagulation Therapy: To manage the blood clot, although this is done cautiously.
  • Surgical Intervention: In severe cases, to relieve pressure or address the underlying cause.
  • Option A) Optic Neuritis primarily presents with visual loss and pain on eye movement, without proptosis or cranial nerve VI palsy as a primary feature.
  • Option B) Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Orbitopathy) typically involves bilateral proptosis, a history of thyroid disease, and ocular motility issues but is less likely to present acutely with severe headache and cranial nerve palsies.
  • Option D) Tolosa-Hunt Syndrome is an idiopathic orbital inflammation that typically responds to corticosteroids and presents with similar symptoms to cavernous sinus thrombosis but without the underlying infection or imaging findings of thrombosis

Key TAKEAWAYS:

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis is often a complication of sinus infections or trauma and can lead to significant ocular and neurological symptoms.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to manage this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: It is widely considered in orthopaedic practice that Ilizarov's ring fixator is the final resort to many failed as well as complex primary fractures. All of the following are indications of Ilizarov's ring fixator except :
questions.solution:
(Option C) Pelvic external fixators are used for complex pelvic injuries and not Ilizarov's ring fixator.

Ilizarov Technique

Applications:

  1. Limb Lengthening: (Option D)
    • Useful for lengthening limbs, especially when shortening is accompanied by deformity.
    • The fixator assembly is designed to correct deformity and produce lengthening simultaneously.
    • Capable of massive limb lengthening (up to 18 inches).
    • Provides a stable biological environment for new bone formation at the lengthening site.
  2. Non-Union:
    • Effective for non-unions resistant to conventional treatments or those associated with deformity or shortening.
    • Can address non-unions requiring skin cover and bone grafting without staged surgeries.
  3. Deformity Correction:
    • Suitable for correcting both congenital and acquired deformities. (Option B)
  4. Osteomyelitis Treatment:
    • Allows for liberal excision of necrotic bone.
    • The resulting gap can be filled by transporting a segment of bone from either end.
  5. Arthrodesis: (Option A)
    • Achieved by "crushing" the articular surfaces together to stimulate union between opposing bones.

questions.text: A child is below the third percentile for height. His growth velocity is normal, but chronologic age is more than skeletal age. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The child in this question has:

  1. Height below 3rd percentile, i.e., short stature.
  2. Normal growth velocity, i.e., normal variant of short stature.
  3. Skeletal age is less than chronological age.

There are two types of normal variant of short stature:

  1. Constitutional delay in growth
  2. Familial genetic short stature

In constitutional delay the bone age is less than chronological age, while in familial short stature bone age is normal for the chronological age.
So, the most likely diagnosis of this child is constitutional delay in growth.

questions.text: Topical application of timolol to the eye would be expected to induce which of the following?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective β-Adrenoceptor blocking agents which reduces aqueous humor formation.

Timolol

  • It is the prototype of ocular β blockers; is nonselective (β1 + β2) and has no local anaesthetic activity.
  • The ocular hypotensive action (20–35% fall in i.o.t.) becomes evident within 1 hour and lasts for ~12 hours the action is smooth and well sustained.
  • Beta-blockers decrease aqueous humor production by blocking β receptors in the ciliary epithelium.

Advantages of topical β blockers

  • No change in pupil size, no diminution of vision in dim light and in patients with cataract
  • No induced myopia which is especially troublesome in young patients
  • No headache/brow pain due to persistent spasm of iris and ciliary muscles
  • No fluctuations in i.o.t. as occur with pilocarpine drops
  • Convenient twice/once daily application sufficient
    • Beta-blockers have negligible effects on pupillary diameter (which is under the control of M3 receptors on the sphincter muscle of the iris and of α1 receptors on the radial muscle of the iris) and on lens curvature (which is mainly under the control of M3 receptors on the ciliary muscle).

Mode of actions for different anti-glaucoma drugs

questions.text: A drunk father who was driving the car had an accident and lost his son who was sitting beside him. He started having severe feeling of guilt that he lost his son because of his drinking habit. After that he stopped drinking and started organizing seminars against drunk driving. He feels very comfortable when he does so. Which type of defense mechanism is this?
questions.solution:
ALTRUISM-

Unconscious/ conscious ego is used in all defence mechanisms.

When you feel good when helping others, it is called altruism.

When a person is planning everything in advance to deal with uncomfortable events, it is anticipation.

Shifting of emotions from one person to another, it is displacement

Offering a rational explanation to justify own unacceptable behaviour is Rationalization.

questions.text: A 10 year old child was brought by a mother with a history of dysphagia. On inquiry she informed that the child was playing alone & gave a history of foreign body ingestion. X-ray was done & images are given. What procedure would be needed in this patient?
questions.solution:
When a child swallows a foreign body, it can either be in the upper airway (trachea) or in the esophagus (the tube that carries food to the stomach). In this case, the child is experiencing dysphagia, which suggests that the foreign body is stuck in the esophagus, as it directly interferes with the process of swallowing.

Here’s why each option is considered:

  • Urgent Bronchoscopy: This procedure is used to visualize the airway (trachea and bronchi), typically when a foreign body is suspected to be lodged in the airway (trachea or lungs). Since the question suggests dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), this points to a foreign body in the esophagus, not the airway, making bronchoscopy less relevant here.
  • Heimlich Maneuver: The Heimlich maneuver is used for choking caused by an object in the airway (trachea). It is not indicated when a foreign body is in the esophagus. The Heimlich maneuver helps to expel a foreign body that is blocking the airway, but it would not help if the object is in the esophagus and may even cause harm.
  • Esophagoscopy: This is the correct procedure. Esophagoscopy involves inserting a scope into the esophagus to directly visualize and retrieve the foreign body. This is the appropriate procedure when a foreign body is lodged in the esophagus and is causing symptoms like dysphagia. This is considered an urgent procedure because the longer a foreign body remains in the esophagus, the more likely it is to cause damage, infection, or other complications.
  • Tracheostomy: This is a surgical procedure to create an opening in the trachea (windpipe) to help with breathing, typically when there is an obstruction in the airway. Since the foreign body is in the esophagus, not the airway, this procedure is not relevant.

The correct answer is C. Esophagoscopy because it is the procedure required to visualize and remove a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms of dysphagia and history of foreign body ingestion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhea. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics and a normal height. On pelvic examination, there is a blind-ending vaginal pouch. Ultrasound shows absent uterus and normal ovaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests a disorder involving congenital absence of the uterus with normal ovarian function, which is characteristic of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome.

OPTION C) Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome:

MRKH syndrome is characterized by congenital absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, with normal external genitalia and normal ovarian function. Patients present with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and a blind-ending vaginal pouch, as described in this case. The normal ovaries support this diagnosis.

OPTION A) Turner syndrome:

Turner syndrome typically presents with short stature, webbed neck, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to ovarian dysgenesis (streak ovaries). It does not match this patient's normal secondary sexual characteristics and normal height.

OPTION B) Androgen insensitivity syndrome:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome presents with primary amenorrhea, normal breast development, absent or sparse pubic and axillary hair, and a blind-ending vaginal pouch. However, these patients have 46,XY karyotype with testes (not ovaries), and their condition is related to androgen resistance, leading to female external genitalia despite XY chromosomes.

OPTION D) Kallmann syndrome:

Kallmann syndrome involves primary amenorrhea with lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia. The presence of normal secondary sexual characteristics in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Topic: Disorders of sexual development

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient presents with an inability to abduct the arm beyond 15 degrees and loss of sensation over the "regimental badge" area . Which of the nerve is likely to be damaged ?
questions.solution:
Axillary nerve (Circumflex nerve) : smaller terminal branch of posterior cord of brachial plexus. (C5,C6). It courses through lower part of axilla into quadrangular space where it terminates by dividing into two branches :

  1. Anterior branch : supply deltoid and skin over its anteroinferior part.
  2. Posterior branch : supplies teres minor and posterior part of deltoid and continues as upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm.

Axillary nerve may be damaged by dislocation of the shoulder or by fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.

The effects produced are :

  • Rounded contour of shoulder is lost
  • Deltoid paralysed with loss of power of abduction up to 90 degrees.
  • sensory loss over the lower half of deltoid in a badge like area called regimental badge.

Axillary nerve and its course

Option wise explanation :

Option A. Radial nerve : Injury leads to paralysis of extensor muscles of arm and forearm. Radial nerve damage results in symptoms of wrist drop and sensory loss over the posterior aspect of the forearm and hand.

Option C. Median nerve : supply the muscles of front of forearm and skin of lateral three and half fingers. Injury lead to inability to flex the wrist and sensory loss over lateral three and half fingers.

Option D. Ulnar nerve : supply the intrinsic muscles of hand and flexor carpi ulnaris and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus. Injury lead to ulnar claw hand and sensory loss over medial one and half fingers.

questions.solution:
Increase in tyrosine level with Skin and Eye lesion with Boiled cabbage odor of urine is suggestive of Disease related with Tyrosine Metabolism specifically Type II tyrosinemia.

Tyrosine Aminotransferase is used in tyrosine metabolism for conversion of Tyrosine to Para hydroxyphenyl pyruvate. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to increase in Serum Tyrosine level.

Option A) Enzyme defect of Fumarylacetate Hydroxylase Fumarylacetoacetate into Fumarate & Acetoacetate & It leads to Type I Tyrosinemia.

choices.text: Petrous fractures can cause CSF Otorrhoea
With cold water irrigation in right ear, the eyes show nystagmus towards the left ear
In BPPV, the Otoconia mostly migrate to Posterior semi-circular canals
Function of Utricle and Saccule is angular acceleration

questions.text: All are true about inner ear except
questions.solution:
• a. Petrous fractures can cause CSF Otorrhoea: True. A fracture in the petrous part of the temporal bone can cause leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the ear, known as CSF otorrhea. This is a known complication of traumatic skull injuries.
  • b. With cold water irrigation in right ear, the eyes show nystagmus towards the left ear: True. This is a response related to the caloric test, which is used to test the vestibular system. Irrigating the right ear with cold water induces a response that causes nystagmus (involuntary eye movement) towards the left side, as the cold water decreases the temperature of the vestibular system, stimulating the opposite side.
  • c. In BPPV, the Otoconia mostly migrate to Posterior semicircular canals: True. In Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), the otoconia (small calcium carbonate crystals) from the utricle migrate into the posterior semicircular canal, causing abnormal stimulation and vertigo. This is the most common type of BPPV.
  • d. Function of Utricle and Saccule is angular acceleration: False. The utricle and saccule are responsible for detecting linear acceleration and the position of the head relative to gravity (static balance). These are part of the vestibular system. Angular acceleration, on the other hand, is detected by the semicircular canals. The semicircular canals respond to rotational movements (angular acceleration) of the head.

OPTION-D

Utricle and Saccule are receptors for linear acceleration

Saccule is responsible for vertical acceleration

Utricle is responsible for horizontal acceleration

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with Scalp lesions, Diabetes insipidus and Hepatosplenomegaly. On investigations -
Immunophenotyping: CD1a+ cells
Electron microscopy shows:

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease where Langerhans cells, which are specialized immune cells, proliferate abnormally and accumulate in various tissues.

The condition can range from a localized disease (such as a solitary bone lesion) to a multisystem disorder affecting multiple organs.

Features:

  1. Clinical Presentation:
    • Bone involvement: Most common manifestation, particularly in the skull, ribs, or long bones, causing bone pain or fractures.
    • X ray depicting double contour or beveled edge appearance due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer tables (hole within a hole) sign
    • Skin lesions: Papules, nodules, or rashes, often resembling eczema or seborrheic dermatitis.
    • Lung involvement: Pulmonary LCH can cause cough and dyspnea, often seen in adult smokers.
    • Endocrine dysfunction: Diabetes insipidus can occur due to pituitary or hypothalamic involvement.
  2. Diagnosis:
    • Histology: Presence of Langerhans cells with characteristic nuclear grooves and positive for CD1a and S100 markers on immunohistochemistry.
    • Electron microscopy: Birbeck granules, also known as Birbeck bodies, are rod shaped or "tennis-racket" cytoplasmic organelles with a central linear density and a striated appearance.
    • Imaging: X-rays, CT, or MRI to assess bone lesions and organ involvement

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma:

  • Benign, self-limiting histiocytic disorder
  • Typically affects children <10 years old
  • Characterized by:
    • Yellowish or orange skin lesions
    • Histiocytic infiltrates with foam cells
    • Absence of systemic involvement
  • Immunophenotype: CD1a+, CD68+, factor XIIIa+


Option C. Rosai-Dorfman Disease (RDD):

  • Rare, benign histiocytic disorder
  • Typically affects children and young adults
  • Characterized by:
    • Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (SHML)
    • Emperipolesis (histiocytes engulfing lymphocytes)
    • Extranodal involvement (skin, bone, CNS)
  • Immunophenotype: CD1a+, CD68+, S-100+

Option D. Erdheim-Chester Disease (ECD):

  • Rare, multisystem histiocytic disorder
  • Typically affects adults
  • Characterized by:
    • Foamy histiocytes in tissues
    • Multifocal xanthogranulomatous lesions
    • Bone involvement (osteosclerosis)
    • Cardiovascular, CNS, and renal involvement
  • Immunophenotype: CD1a+, CD68+, S-100+

questions.solution:

questions.text: Cyanide odour is of:
questions.solution:
The bitter almond odour of hydrocyanic acid may be noticed on opening the body. About 20 to 40% persons cannot smell the gas, and the ability to detect it is a sex-linked recessive trait.

In cases of suspected cyanide poisoning, the cranial cavity should be opened first, as the odour is usually well-marked in the brain tissues.

External postmortem findings in case of cyanide poisoning

  1. Smell of bitter almonds near the body.
  2. Face, lips and body surfaces show irregular pink patches, or rarely, cyanotic tinge.
  3. Bright red postmortem lividity
  4. Fine froth at the mouth.
  5. Eyes: Bright, glistening, prominent with dilated pupils.
  6. Rigor mortis appears early.
  7. Jaws are firmly closed.

Diagnostic Odour in Poisoning:

questions.text: Look at the image of the virus particle. What virus is shown?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus-Space vehicle appearance Adenovirus has an icosahedral shape, which means it is a symmetrical, 20-sided structure. The virus is non-enveloped and its capsid is made up of 252 protein subunits called capsomeres, arranged in an icosahedron.

Each vertex of the icosahedron has a fiber-like projection, called a penton, which helps the virus attach to and infect host cells.

  • A) HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus has an enveloped structure with an icosahedral capsid inside, but it is enveloped, not naked like the virus shown.
  • B) Papillomavirus: Papillomavirus is also icosahedral but is smaller and lacks the complex protein shell seen here.
  • C) Adenovirus: Adenovirus has a distinctive icosahedral capsid with a complex protein structure and lacks an envelope, matching the image description.
  • D) HPV: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is similar to Papillomavirus, with a simpler structure compared to the image shown.

Key Takeaway: Adenovirus is characterized by its icosahedral shape with a complex protein shell, which is crucial for identifying it.

Reference:For more information on Adenovirus, refer to the CDC:https://www.cdc.gov/adenovirus/about/index.html

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of HIV presents with sudden-onset floaters, visual disturbances, and a decline in vision. On examination, the patient shows retinal lesions that are pale and have a characteristic "owl-eye" appearance. Fluorescein angiography reveals hemorrhages and areas of retinal necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis Overview

  1. Etiology:
    • Pathogen: Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpesvirus family.
    • Common in: Immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS, transplant recipients, and patients on immunosuppressive therapy.
  2. Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms: Floaters, blurred vision, vision loss, and photopsia.
    • Signs:
      • Retinal Lesions: Pale, necrotic areas with well-defined borders.
      • "Owl-Eye" Appearance: Characteristic inclusions visible in histopathology.
      • Retinal Hemorrhages: Often associated with the necrotic lesions.
      • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows retinal hemorrhages, and areas of retinal necrosis and inflammation.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Clinical Examination: Characteristic retinal findings.
    • Fluorescein Angiography: Reveals retinal damage and hemorrhages.
    • Ocular Imaging: Can help visualize extent of retinal damage.
    • Laboratory Tests: PCR testing of the vitreous or aqueous humor can confirm CMV DNA.
  4. Treatment:
    • Antiviral Therapy: Medications such as ganciclovir, foscarnet, or cidofovir are used to manage CMV retinitis.

Management of Immunosuppression: Addressing the underlying immunosuppressive condition is critical.

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. It is characterized by retinal necrosis with "owl-eye" inclusions seen on histology. Fluorescein angiography typically shows retinal hemorrhages and necrotic lesions.
  • Diabetic Retinopathy presents with retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and neovascularization, but not the characteristic "owl-eye" lesions or necrotic retinal areas seen in CMV retinitis.
  • Age-related Macular Degeneration primarily affects the macula, leading to central vision loss, drusen, and possibly choroidal neovascularization, but it does not present with the necrotic retinal lesions seen in CMV retinitis.
  • Retinal Vein Occlusion may show retinal hemorrhages and exudates but lacks the distinctive retinal necrosis and "owl-eye" inclusions characteristic of CMV retinitis.

#ocular presentation of AIDS #CMV retinitis

Imaging Studies in Spinal Tumors

  • MRI:

  • CT Scan:
    • Provides information on bony involvement and mechanical stability.
  • CT-Guided Needle Biopsy:
    • Often possible when the primary tumor is unknown.
    • May avoid the need for surgical open biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetic agent is contraindicated in epileptic patients posted for general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ketamine should be avoided in patients who have a history of seizures since it raises ICP and produces delirium and hallucinations.

Ketamine is a sympathomimetic drug as it inhibits the metabolism of catecholamines and can, therefore, trigger seizures.

Ketamine increases cerebral metabolism, CBF, and ICP. Because of its excitatory CNS effects, which can be detected by generalized EEG development of theta wave activity and by petit mal seizure-like activity in the hippocampus.

Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine and is seen in 30-40% of the people.

Auditory hallucinations are more common than visual hallucinations.

Other options:

  • Option A: Propofol may suppress seizure activity via GABA agonism, inhibition of NMDA receptors, and modulation of slow calcium ion channels. Propofol has neuroprotective action.
  • Option B & D: Thiopentone and Midazolam have anti-epileptic property as they act via the GABA-A receptors to release GABA. Thiopentone has anticonvulsant action due to its phenyl group. Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used in treatment of seizures.

Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth.

questions.text:
Identify the Parasite from the Image
The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
• A) Incorrect: Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.
  • B) Correct: Ancylostoma duodenale (Hookworm) features a hook-like anterior end and may have cutting plates or teeth. It has segmented eggs with blastomeres.
  • C) Incorrect: Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is smaller and characterized by rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, unlike the hook-like structure.
  • D) Incorrect: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.

Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) can be identified by their segmented appearance with blastomeres. This distinguishes them from other parasitic worms based on morphological features.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: Which type of refractive error is this?

Choose the option with the correct statement about inter-vertebral discs (IVD):
1. Nucleus pulposus is derived from ectoderm
2. Annulus fibrosus is derived from mesoderm
3. Nutrition of IVD is derived through diffusion through CSF
4. IVD allows spinal motion and stability.
questions.solution:
Intervertebral Discs (IVDs)

  • Functions:
    • Allow spinal motion and stability. (Option D)
    • Act as cushioning for axial loads on the spine.
  • Components:
    1. Central Nucleus Pulposus:
      • Derived from the notochord. (Option A)
      • Hydrated gel with compressibility.
      • Low collagen (type II) and high proteoglycan (and glycosaminoglycan) content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a higher percentage of dry weight.
      • With time, undergoes loss of proteoglycans and water (desiccation).
    2. Surrounding Annulus Fibrosis:
      • Derived from mesoderm. (Option B)
      • Provides extensibility and increased tensile strength.
      • High collagen (type I) and low proteoglycan content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a lower percentage of dry weight.
      • Superficial layer contains nerve fibers.
  • Composition:
    • Water: 85%
    • Proteoglycans
    • Type II Collagen: 20% of dry weight in the nucleus pulposus.
    • Type I Collagen: 60% of dry weight in the annulus fibrosis.
  • Neurovascularity:
    • Dorsal Root Ganglion: Gives rise to the sinuvertebral nerve, innervating the superficial fibers of the annulus.
    • Avascular: Nutrients and fluid diffuse from the vertebral end plates. Diffusion is impaired by calcification with aging. (Option C)
  • Aging Disc:
    • Early Degenerative Disc Disease:
      • An irreversible process.
      • IL-1β stimulates the release of MMPs, nitric oxide, IL-6, and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2).
    • Changes:
      • Decreased water content and conversion to fibrocartilage.
      • Decreased hydrostatic pressure due to fewer large proteoglycans (aggrecan).
      • Fibronectin cleavage or fragmentation is associated with degeneration.
      • Increase in keratan sulfate concentration and decrease in chondroitin sulfate.
      • Increase in relative collagen concentration, with no change in absolute quantity.

questions.text: A gynecologist refers a young mother to you for second opinion for prenatal genetic counseling. She is 20 week's pregnant and had a prenatal ultrasound last week that was normal. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated thus far. Her brother and maternal uncle have Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Last week at her ultrasound, she found out she is having a girl. What is the risk of her daughter being affected by DMD if the mother is a carrier?
questions.solution:
• DMD is an X-linked recessive disorder.
  • Only males are affected. X-linked traits are never passed from father to son.
  • If a mother is a carrier, then 50% of her sons will be affected and 50% of her daughters will be carriers. All daughters are unaffected.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man had progressive deafness and hematuria from childhood and had undergone renal transplant eight years ago for chronic renal failure. Examination revealed perceptive high-tone deafness and anterior lenticonus in both eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient had developed chronic kidney disease in his early life itself with involvement of eyes and ears, suggestive of an inherited disorder. Among the given options Alport’s syndrome causes all of the above

Alport's syndrome

Genetics: X-linked inheritance of mutations in the α5(IV) collagen chain

Characterised by a triad of

  • Progressive hematuric nephritis
  • Progressive perceptive high-tone hearing loss
  • Ocular signs(cataracts, spherophakia and anterior lenticonus, dot and fleck retinopathy)

Renal Biopsy:

Early features: thin basement membranes on renal biopsy which thicken over time into multilamellations surrounding lucent areas that often contain granules of varying density-the so-called split basement membrane.

Advanced disease: Tubules drop out, glomeruli scar and the kidney eventually succumbs to interstitial fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with Intracranial aneurysms, hepatic cysts, mitral valve prolapse, abdominal wall hernias and colonic diverticulae.

NF is associated with stenosis of renal vessels.

Romanoward syndrome is a congenital long QT syndrome without deafness. Jervell's Syndrome is another congenital long QT syndrome with deafness.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman suffering from rheumatoid arthritis started a treatment that included infliximab, a monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α). The drug has a volume of distribution of about 3L. Which of the following is most likely the main site of distribution of this drug?
questions.solution:
• Because the volume of plasma in a person weighing 70 kg is about 3 L, it can be deduced that drugs with a volume of distribution of about 3L distribute in plasma.
  • In fact, infliximab is a large molecule that cannot leave the vascular compartment.
  • It binds to and neutralizes TNF-α in the blood, thus preventing the actions of this cytokine.

Volume of distribution (Vd)

  • It is the volume that would be required to contain the administered dose if that dose was evenly distributed at the concentration measured in plasma.
  • If more amount of drug is entering the tissues, it has a higher volume of distribution and vice-a-versa.
  • It depends on several factors like lipid solubility and plasma protein binding.
  • Drugs which are lipid soluble are more likely to cross the blood vessel wall and thus have high volume of distribution.
  • If a drug is highly bound to plasma proteins, (e.g., warfarin, benzodiazepines, furosemide, calcium channel blockers, digitoxin etc.) it will behave like a large molecule and more likely to stay in the plasma. Therefore, less will go to tissues resulting in reduced volume of distribution
  • The volume of distribution (Vd) is calculated by dividing the total amount of the drug in the body by its plasma concentration.
  • Vd = Dose administered (I.V.)/Plasma concentration

Factors governing volume of drug distribution

  • Lipid: water partition coefficient of the drug
  • pKa value of the drug
  • Degree of plasma protein binding
  • Affinity for different tissues
  • Fat: lean body mass ratio, which can vary with age, sex, obesity, etc.
  • Diseases like CHF, uremia, cirrhosis

Tags:

  • Volume of distribution
  • Must Know

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman suddenly deteriorates 2 days after receiving thrombolytic therapy for acute myocardial infarction. She complained of severe shortness of breath with an O2 saturation of 91% despite oxygen supplementation. On examination her BP is 105/70 mmHg, with a pulse of 105/min, regular. She has an apical systolic murmur and bilateral basal crepitations.

Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The posteromedial papillary muscle is twice as likely to rupture as the anterolateral one because the posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied by the right coronary artery only, whereas the anterolateral papillary muscle receives supply from both the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.
  • The murmur (apical pansystolic) is consistent with mitral regurgitation which in turn leads to acute left ventricular failure.
  • Management is based on decreasing afterload to stabilize patients before undergoing valvular surgery; sodium nitroprusside is the usual therapy of choice where blood pressure allows.

questions.text: A 45 years old patient is having uncontrolled diabetes with HbA1c value 9.8% & not on regular treatment. All the following enzymes is inhibited except
questions.solution:
Uncontrolled diabetes with a high HbA1c value (9.8%) is a state of fasting (insulin deficient state), Various catabolic metabolic Pathway related to Carbohydrate, lipids and protein metabolism are activated due to decreased insulin action.

Hormone Sensitive Lipase is involved in breakdown of stored fat (Lipolysis) action Inhibited by Insulin while Lipoprotein lipase activity is reduced due to decreased Insulin Signalling.

  • Lipoprotein lipase involved in Hydrolysis of Triglycerides in Lipoprotein into free fatty acid and Glycerol.
  • Glycogen Synthase: Insulin induces the action of Glycogen Synthase. In uncontrolled diabetes In diabetes, particularly with high blood glucose levels, glycogen synthase activity is typically decreased.
  • Insulin normally activates glycogen synthase to promote glycogen synthesis, but in uncontrolled diabetes, this activation is impaired.
  • Phosphofructokinase I (PFK-1): Enzyme is activated by Insulin In uncontrolled diabetes, where insulin action is impaired, PFK-1 activity is reduced due to decreased insulin levels or resistance.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to casualty with severe chest pain. ECG was suggestive of anterior wall ST elevation MI. He underwent thrombolysis with reteplase with good resolution of ECG changes. On day 3, he developed sharp chest pain, worse with inspiration and movement and improved with NSAIDs. On day 5, patient has progressive dyspnea. His heart rate was 110/min, BP was 90/50 mmHg with elevated JVP. What is the most likely complication that has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The presence of typical sharp chest pain which increases on inspiration is suggestive of pericarditis. However, it would not per se lead to hypotension and raised JVP as seen in this patient.
  • Cardiac tamponade can occur as a rare complication in post-MI patients. It is the rapid accumulation of fluid in pericardial sac under pressure.
  • The typical clinical triad seen in tamponade is 'Beck's triad' (low BP, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds)
  • The development of acute mitral regurgitation or VSD is associated with severe pulmonary oedema and less likely to be associated with chest pain.

questions.text: Lucid interval is seen in
questions.solution:
Lucid interval in Psychiatry: This is a period occurring in mental illness, during which all the symptoms of mental illness disappear completely. The individual is able to judge his acts soundly, and he becomes legally liable for his acts. The period of lucid interval varies from person to person and from time to time in the same person, and as such one cannot be certain about the time when a person passes again in the state of mental illness. Therefore, if he commits an offence, he cannot be completely held responsible, because it is very difficult to know, whether he was suffering from some mental abnormality at the time of committing the offence. In mania and melancholia lucid intervals are common.

Lucid interval in head injury: Lucid interval is the period of consciousness between two periods of unconsciousness. The classic lucid interval occurs in 30 -40% of patients with EDH. Initially, the concussive force that caused the head injury results in an alteration of consciousness. After consciousness is recovered, the EDH continues to expand until the mass effect of the haemorrhage itself results in increased intracranial pressure, a decreased level of consciousness, and a possible herniation syndrome.

choices.text: Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides): Characterized by its large, cylindrical shape and smooth surface.
Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth.
Strongyloides (Strongyloides stercoralis): Known for its small size and the presence of rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity.
Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura): Recognizable by its thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end.

questions.text: The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
A) Incorrect: Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.

B) Correct: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) have a hook-like anterior end and often feature cutting plates or teeth, which are visible in the image.

C) Incorrect: Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is characterized by its small size and rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, not the hook-like structure.

D) Incorrect: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end, and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.

Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) are identified by their hook-like anterior end and presence of cutting plates or teeth. This morphological feature is crucial for distinguishing them from other parasitic worms.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: What is Nipple confusion?
questions.solution:
• A problem that may be seen in a bottle-fed baby in which it forgets how to nurse on mother’s nipple
  • Breastfeeding requires far more vigorous mouth and tongue motions and greater muscle coordination than bottle-feeding.
  • On bottle nipples or even pacifiers, a newborn can forget how to nurse properly.
  • This confusion can lead to diminished or discontinued nursing. Nipple confusion is usually not a concern after the early weeks, once the baby is nursing well.

questions.text: A 2 year old girl was brought to the emergency department by her mother after ingesting several tablets of a medication containing iron. An emergency treatment was started that included the intravenous administration of desferrioxamine. This drug is able to combine with iron in plasma to form an inactive complex and therefore to antagonize iron effects. Which of the following terms best describes this antagonism?
questions.solution:
• Chemical antagonism is said to occur when a drug combines chemically with the drug to be antagonized, making that drug pharmacologically inactive, as in the present example.
  • A chemical antagonist does not act on receptors or on the pharmacokinetics of the drug to be antagonized.

Examples of chemical antagonism:

  • KMnO4 oxidizes alkaloids-used for gastric lavage in poisoning.
  • Tannins + alkaloids-insoluble alkaloidal tannate is formed.
  • Chelating agents (BAL, Cal. disod. edetate) complex toxic metals (As, Pb).
  • Nitrites form methaemoglobin which reacts with cyanide radical.

Option A: Competitive antagonism

The antagonist is chemically similar to the agonist, competes with it and binds to the same site of the agonist molecules.

Because the antagonist has affinity but no intrinsic activity, no response is produced and the log DRC of the agonist is shifted to the right.

Option B: Noncompetitive antagonism

The antagonist is chemically unrelated to the agonist, binds to a different allosteric site altering the receptor in such a way that it is unable to combine with the agonist or is unable to transduce the response.

Increasing concentrations of the antagonist progressively flatten the agonist DRC

Option C: Physiological/functional antagonism

The two drugs act on different receptors or by different mechanisms, but have opposite overt effects on the same physiological function,

i.e. have pharmacological effects in opposite direction, e.g.

  • Histamine and adrenaline on bronchial muscles and on BP.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide and amiloride on urinary K+ excretion.
  • Glucagon and insulin on blood sugar level.

Tags:

  • Chemical antagonism
  • Good to Know

questions.text: Which of the following cells play a role in the defense mechanisms of the respiratory tract?
questions.solution:
• Option B) Club cells also known as Clara cells are nonciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete protective proteins and enzymes, contributing to the detoxification of harmful substances and repair of the airway epithelium.
  • Option A) Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic cells found in the epidermis, particularly in the stratum spinosum. Langerhans cells capture and process antigens that enter through the skin and then migrate to the lymph nodes to present these antigens to T-cells, initiating an adaptive immune response.
  • Option C) Type I alveolar cells are epithelial cells found in the alveoli in the lungs. These cells help in exchange of gases through the membrane.
  • Option D) Kupffer cells are liver-resident macrophages that play a critical role in filtering the blood, clearing pathogens, dead cells, and toxins. They are also involved in iron metabolism and immune surveillance within the liver.

questions.text: Which cells in the stomach produces gastrin?
questions.solution:
Endocrine cells

  • The stomach has numerous endocrine cells, which are critical to its function.
  • In the gastric antrum, the mucosa contains G cells, which produce gastrin.
  • Throughout the body of the stomach, enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells are abundant and produce histamine, a key factor in driving gastric acid secretion.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man has presented with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 40 beats per minute. Upon investigation he has the following results:

Sodium 132 mmol/l, Potassium 7.6mmol/l, Urea 122 mg/dl, Creatinine 4.7 mg/dl

(Ref values: S. creat: 0.6-1.4 mg/dl; S. urea: 17 - 43 mg/dL; S. sodium: 135-145 mEq/L; S. potassium: 3.5-5 mEq/L)

What should be the initial management?
questions.solution:
This question deals with symptomatic hyperkalemia in renal failure.

Hyperkalemia has serious effects on the cardiac conduction and hence is a medical emergency.

The initial therapy of hyperkalemia with cardiac conduction problems is to antagonise the eddect of potassium on heart by giving calcium gluconate. The best and the most effective treatment is hemodilysis especially if associated with renal failure.

Immediate Antagonism of Cardiac Effects of Hyperkalemia: Intravenous calcium gluconate is administered to protect the heart. Calcium raises the action potential threshold and reduces excitability, effectively reversing the depolarization blockade caused by hyperkalemia. The recommended dose is 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate, infused intravenously over 2-3 minutes, with cardiac monitoring. The effect starts within 1-3 minutes and lasts for 30-60 minutes.

  1. Rapid Reduction in Plasma K+ Concentration by Redistribution into Cells:
    • Insulin and Dextrose: Insulin is used to shift potassium into cells. The recommended dose is 10 units of intravenous regular insulin followed immediately by 50 mL of 50% dextrose. The effect begins in 10-20 minutes, peaks at 30-60 minutes, and lasts for 4-6 hours. This is followed by an infusion of 10% dextrose to prevent hypoglycemia.
    • β2-Agonists (e.g., Albuterol): These are effective in reducing plasma K+ concentration but should be used cautiously in hyperkalemic patients with known cardiac disease. The recommended dose for inhaled albuterol is 10-20 mg in 4 mL of normal saline, inhaled over 10 minutes.
    • Intravenous Bicarbonate: While not used for acute treatment, bicarbonate may slowly attenuate hyperkalemia when infused over several hours. It should be infused in an isotonic or hypotonic fluid.
  2. Removal of Potassium:
    • Cation Exchange Resins (Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate - SPS): These exchange sodium for potassium in the gastrointestinal tract, increasing fecal excretion of potassium. The full effect may take up to 24 hours and may require repeated doses. However, SPS can have rare but serious side effects, including intestinal necrosis.
    • Novel Intestinal Potassium Binders (e.g., Patiromer, ZS-9): These are alternatives to SPS that promise safer and more effective management of hyperkalemia.
    • Diuretics: Loop and thiazide diuretics can help reduce plasma K+ concentration in volume-replete or hypervolemic patients with sufficient renal function.
    • Hemodialysis: This is the most effective method to reduce plasma K+ concentration, especially in cases of severe hyperkalemia. Patients with acute kidney injury or advanced chronic kidney disease may require hemodialysis. Peritoneal dialysis is less effective.

questions.text: Activation of Oncogene in Burkitt Lymphoma is the example of
questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma is associated with Epstein Barr virus.

  • The chromosomes involved are 8 and 14. The letters p and q refer to the short and long arms of the chromosomes respectively, while the white oval, labeled CEN, is the centromere.
  • Only a portion of each chromosome is shown. A segment from the end of the q arm of chromosome 8 breaks off and translocates to chromosome 14.
  • The reverse process moves a small segment from the q arm of chromosome 14 to chromosome 8; these translocations involve regions q24 (chromosome 8) and q32 (chromosome 14).
  • The MYC gene is contained in the small piece of chromosome 8 that was transferred to chromosome 14. Thus, MYC is placed adjacent to the genes transcribing the heavy chains of immunoglobulin molecules, and MYC gene transcription is activated by the potent IgG H gene enhancer

Mechanisms by which Oncogenes are Activated

questions.text: Hospital acquired pneumonia can be labelled if it develops after __ hours after hospital admission.
questions.solution:
• Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) occurs more than 48 hours after admission to the hospital or other health care facility and excludes any infection present at the time of admission.
  • If it develops within 48 hours it is considered as community acquired pneumonia (CAP)
  • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) develops more than 48 hours following endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • It presents as At least two of the following: fever, leucocytosis, purulent sputum OR a new or progressive parenchymal opacities on chest radiograph.

questions.text: Doctrine of 'Res Ipsa Loquitur' can be applied in case of
questions.solution:
• Res ipsa loquitur means, the thing speaks for itself.
  • This doctrine is applied both in civil and criminal negligence.
  • The legal and procedural effect of the Court's acceptance of res ipsa loquitar in a negligence action is to shift the burden of proof from the plaintiff (patient) to one of disproof by the defendant (Doctor).
  • This doctrine cannot be applied against several defendants (i.e. doctors).
  • To prove Doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur, the following conditions should be satisfied:
    1. That in absence of negligence, the injury would not have occurred.
    2. Patient has not contributed to negligence.
    3. Doctor had exclusive control of the circumstances or injury producing instruments or treatment.

E.g.: Amputation of wrong digit or limb, Leaving a swab or instrument in abdomen of patient after operation, Prescription of overdose etc.

questions.text: The image below shows a microscopic view of malaria parasites in a blood smear. Based on this morphology, which parasite is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• The presence of banana-shaped gametocytes in a blood smear is a hallmark diagnostic feature for Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
  • Typically detected through Giemsa-stained blood smears under microscopy.
  • These are the sexual forms of the parasite, known as gametocytes, which are taken up by mosquitoes during a blood meal and are crucial for transmission.
  • The gametocytes develop over time inside red blood cells, and the mature male and female gametocytes are responsible for reproduction within the mosquito gut.

A) Correct: Plasmodium falciparum is known for its distinctive crescent or banana-shaped gametocytes, which are clearly visible in the image.

B) Incorrect: Plasmodium vivax gametocytes are more rounded or oval-shaped, and its ring forms do not have the banana shape seen in the image.

C) Incorrect: Plasmodium malariae typically presents with banded trophozoites and smaller ring forms, not the banana-shaped gametocytes.

D) Incorrect: Plasmodium ovale has oval-shaped schizonts and Schüffner's dots, which do not match the banana-shaped appearance in the image.

Key Takeaway:
Plasmodium falciparum is identified by its unique banana-shaped gametocytes, which is a critical feature for diagnosis in blood smears.

CLINICAL RELEVANCE- While these gametocytes do not contribute to clinical symptoms, they are key for the parasite's transmission to mosquitoes, thus continuing the malaria life cycle.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference:

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Malaria. https://www.cdc.gov/malaria/

  • Option C) Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchi, leading to mucus production, airway narrowing, and airflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady has a headache, cough and myalgia. On examination, she has a pyrexia and scattered crackles bilaterally on auscultation of the chest. Rapid cold agglutinins were positive. What is the likely diagnosis?

  • Approximately 15% of pneumonias in adults are due to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Transmission occurs from person to person by infected droplets. The incubation period is 9-21 days. The incidence is higher during the winter months. Fever, chills, cough and headache are early symptoms. Dyspnoea, chest pain and haemoptysis are rare.

questions.text: Which artery is the main blood supply of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
• The small intestine has a very rich blood supply, derived from the superior mesenteric artery, while venous drainage is via the portal venous system, into which the superior mesenteric vein drains blood rich in nutrients after a meal.
  • This arrangement facilitates processing of the nutrients by the liver, into which the portal vein drains in turn.
  • The lymphatic drainage of the small intestine follows the arterial supply.

questions.text: Infarctions secondary to low flow in the "watershed" between the distal PCA and MCA territories, as occurs after cardiac arrest is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Bilateral visual association area lesions may result in Balint's syndrome, a disorder of the orderly visual scanning of the environment, usually resulting from infarctions secondary to low flow in the "watershed" between the distal PCA and MCA territories, as occurs after cardiac arrest. Patients may experience persistence of a visual image for several minutes despite gazing at another scene (palinopsia) or an inability to synthesize the whole of an image (simultagnosia)
  • Anton's syndrome occurs due to bilateral occlusion of distal posterior cerebral arteries. It produces cortical blindness (blindness with preserved pupillary light reaction). The patient is often unaware of the blindness or may even deny it.
  • Wallenberg's syndrome is lateral medullary syndrome which occurs due to occlusion of vertebral arteries. It results in acute onset ataxia, dizziness, Horner's syndrome and contralateral sensory loss.
