questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with type-1 diabetes mellitus came for her routine review and says she is keen on becoming pregnant. Which of the following is the factor most likely to make you ask her to defer pregnancy at this stage?
questions.solution:
• Pregnancy in type-1 diabetes is still associated with a two- to threefold increase in congenital abnormalities when compared with the background population.
  • It is also associated with higher neonatal morbidity and mortality and higher operative delivery rates.
  • Prepregnancy counselling with the aim of bringing the Hb A1c to near-normal levels are associated with better pregnancy outcomes.
  • Diabetic retinopathy can progress during pregnancy and the eyes must be checked at least once each trimester; if there is progression that is sight-threatening then the patient should be referred to an ophthalmologist. Background retinopathy would not be a contraindication to pregnancy.
  • The albumin level is within normal limits.
  • Nephropathy can also progress during pregnancy, but microalbuminuria would not be a contraindication to pregnancy and nor would sensory neuropathy.
  • It is important that patients with diabetes take 5 mg folic acid daily prepregnancy (this reduces neural tube defects) and this can be started when the patient starts trying to conceive, although it should ideally be taken for 3 months before hand.
  • The most important thing this woman can do is to improve her glycaemic control before trying to conceive.

• Nocardia is an aerobe, catalase positive and weakly acid fast bacteria.
  • Characterized by branching, filamentous bacteria.
  • It causes disease similar to tuberculosis but with PPD negative.

A) Nocardiosis: Characterized by branching, filamentous bacteria that are weakly acid-fast. Nocardia species are known for these features.

B) Aspergillosis: Caused by Aspergillus species, which have septate hyphae with acute-angle branching, not filamentous bacteria

C) Actinomycosis: Caused by Actinomyces species, which show branching filaments but do not have the weak acid-fast characteristic of Nocardia.

D) Mycobacteriosis: Caused by Mycobacterium species, which are strongly acid-fast rods, differing from the weakly acid-fast nature of Nocardia.

Key Takeaway:Nocardia infections are identified by weakly acid-fast, branching filamentous bacteria. This is important for distinguishing them from other filamentous infections.

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient with history of congestive heart failure was prescribed furosemide by his physician for relief from his congestive symptoms due to CHF. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality is most likely to be found in the serum of this patient due to continuous furosemide usage?
questions.solution:
Furosemide leads to

Hypokalemia,

Hypomagnesemia, and

Metabolic alkylosis (elevated bicarbonate level).

Hypokalaemia

This is the most significant Problem

Degree of hypokalaemia appears to be related to the duration of action of the diuretic; longer acting drugs cause more K+ loss.

The usual manifestations are weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.

Hypokalaemia is less common with standard doses of high ceiling diuretics than with thiazides

Hypokalaemia can be prevented and treated by:

(a) High dietary K+ intake or

(b) Supplements of KCl (24-72 mEq/day) or

(c) Concurrent use of K+ sparing diuretics.

Alkalosis may occur with hypokalaemia, because more H+ exchanges with Na+ in DT when less K+ is available for exchange.

[Furosemide]

[Good to Know]

A patient with a chronic cough and night sweats presents for evaluation. The image shows rod-shaped bacteria that are acid-fast

Which bacterial pathogen is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
M. tuberculosis has a high lipid content in its cell wall, primarily due to mycolic acids, making it acid-fast. This means it retains certain dyes even after being washed with acidic alcohol.

  • Stain the smear with carbol fuchsin (a red dye).
  • Heat the slide to facilitate dye penetration.
  • Decolorize the smear with acid-alcohol.
  • Counterstain with methylene blue.

Appearance: M. tuberculosis appears as red or pink rod-shaped bacilli against a blue background (the rest of the cells and debris).

A) Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Acid-fast rods, characteristic of M. tuberculosis.

B) Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods, not acid-fast.

C) Mycobacterium leprae: Also acid-fast rods, but more often associated with leprosy.

D) Corynebacterium diphtheriae: Gram-positive rods, not acid-fast.

Key Takeaway:Mycobacterium tuberculosis is identified by its acid-fast staining properties.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent diplopia and drooping of the upper eyelids that worsens as the day progresses. On examination, the patient shows improved eyelid elevation when the patient is asked to look upward and a significant reduction in diplopia after rest. Which of the following tests would be most indicative of the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option C) Tensilon (Edrophonium) Test: This is a diagnostic test for myasthenia gravis. Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that temporarily improves muscle strength in patients with myasthenia gravis, thereby reducing ptosis and diplopia. A positive response supports the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis

Ocular myasthenia gravis

form of myasthenia gravis primarily affecting the muscles controlling eye movements and eyelid function. It is characterized by:

  1. Ptosis (Drooping Eyelids): Often one-sided and worsens with sustained eye opening. Can become more pronounced as the day progresses due to muscle fatigue.
  2. Diplopia (Double Vision): Usually due to weakness of the extraocular muscles, leading to misalignment of the eyes.
  3. Fatiguability: Symptoms typically improve with rest and worsen with activity. This is due to the progressive nature of muscle weakness over time.
  4. Testing and Diagnosis:
    • Tensilon (Edrophonium) Test: Demonstrates temporary improvement in symptoms with the administration of edrophonium, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
    • Ice Pack Test: Application of an ice pack to the eyes can temporarily alleviate ptosis in some patients, suggesting myasthenia gravis.
    • Serologic Testing: Detection of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies supports the diagnosis.
  5. Management:
    • Anticholinesterase Medications: Such as pyridostigmine, which help improve neuromuscular transmission.
    • Immunosuppressive Therapy: May be used for more severe cases or when anticholinesterase medications are insufficient.
    • Thymectomy: Surgical removal of the thymus gland may be considered in certain patients, especially those with associated thymoma.

Option A) Fundus Examination: While important in assessing retinal health, it does not help diagnose myasthenia gravis.

Option B) CT Scan of the Orbit: Useful in ruling out structural abnormalities or other causes of ocular symptoms but does not diagnose myasthenia gravis.

Option D) Goldmann Visual Field Test: Assesses the visual field but does not provide information on muscle strength or diagnose myasthenia gravis

questions.text: A 38 year old woman was taking ibuprofen as and when required basis for severe dysmenorrhea as a part of self medication but later develops epigastric pain. On consulting the physician for the relief from epigastric pain he prescribes a medication to prevent gastritis. Which of the following option is best describes the medication prescribed?
questions.solution:
• PGE 1 analog, misoprostol, is used to prevent NSAID-associated gastritis
  • The patient’s history and symptoms suggest that she was at risk of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)−induced ulcer.
  • Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of prostaglandin E1, is the drug most often prescribed, as it is able to prevent (but not to treat) NSAID-induced ulcers.
  • This preventive effect is most likely due to the following mechanisms:
  • At low doses, misoprostol activates prostaglandin receptors on superficial epithelial cells of the stomach, increasing bicarbonate and mucus secretion (the so-called cytoprotective effect).
  • At higher doses, it activates prostaglandin receptors on parietal cells of the stomach, decreasing gastric acid secretion (most likely the main mechanism).
  • PGE2 and PGI2 decrease acid secretion and increase mucus production and mucosal blood flow. All these factors decrease the chances of peptic ulcer.
  • NSAIDs on long term use can precipitate Peptic ulcer disease due to inhibition of PG synthesis.
  • Misoprostol is the most specific drug for the treatment of peptic ulcer due to chronic NSAID use. [Remember, the drug of choice is proton pump inhibitors]
  • PGE2 and PGF2α cause diarrhea and colicky pain in the abdomen. These symptoms are important side effects of these drugs.

questions.text: Which among the following disease shows redcurrant jelly stools and sausage shaped lump?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of intussusception

  • The classical presentation of intussusception is with episodes of screaming and drawing up of the legs in a previously well male infant. The attacks last for a few minutes and recur repeatedly.
  • During attacks the child appears pale; between episodes he may be listless.
  • Vomiting may or may not occur at the outset but becomes conspicuous and bilestained with time.
  • Initially, the passage of stool may be normal, whereas, later, blood and mucus are evacuated - the 'redcurrant jelly' stool.
  • Whenever possible, examination should be undertaken between episodes of colic, without disturbing the child.
  • Classically, the abdomen is not initially distended; a lump that hardens on palpation may be discerned but this is present in only 60% of cases.
  • There may be an associated feeling of emptiness in the right iliac fossa (the sign of Dance).
  • On rectal examination, blood-stained mucus may be found on the finger.
  • Occasionally, in extensive ileocolic or colocolic intussusception, the apex may be palpable or even protrude from the anus.
  • Unrelieved, progressive dehydration and abdominal distension from small bowel obstruction will occur, followed by peritonitis secondary to gangrene. Rarely, natural cure may occur as a result of sloughing of the intussusception.

questions.text: A 25 year old female patient presented to hospital with several bouts of vomiting and treated with an anti-emetic drug by attending physician. Vomiting subsided but after sometime, she developed abnormal movements and a dystonic posture (as shown in the image below). Which of the following drug is used for treatment of these motor symptoms?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonias

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles -grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most during treatment with Dopaminergic antagonist therapy.
  • Here mostly Metoclopramide is given as an anti-emetic drug and as it is dopaminergic antagonist it has created acute dystonia as side effect.
  • One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Central anticholinergics

  • The central anticholinergics act by reducing the unbalanced cholinergic activity in the striatum of parkinsonian patients.
  • Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug (phenothiazines, other D2 antagonists) induced parkinsonism.

Option A, C & D: All other agents are not effective in acute muscular dystonia.

questions.text: Which among the following disease shows cobblestone appearance of the intestine?
questions.solution:
Gross pathologic features.

  • At exploration, thickened Gray pink or dull purple-red loops of bowel are noted, with areas of thick gray-white exudate or fibrosis of the serosa.
  • Areas of diseased bowel separated by areas of grossly appearing normal bowel, called skip areas, are commonly encountered.
  • A striking finding of Crohn disease is the presence of extensive fat wrapping caused by the circumferential growth of the mesenteric fat around the bowel wall, also known as creeping fat.
  • As the disease progresses, the bowel wall becomes increasingly thickened, firm, rubbery, and almost incompressible.
  • The uninvolved proximal bowel may be dilated secondary to obstruction of the diseased Involved segments often are adherent to adjacent intestinal loops or other viscera, with internal fistulas common in these areas.
  • The mesentery of the involved segment is usually thickened, with enlarged lymph nodes often noted.
  • On opening of the bowel, the earliest gross pathologic lesion is a superficial aphthous ulcer noted in the mucosa.
  • With increasing disease progression, the ulceration becomes pronounced, and complete ;transmural inflammation
  • The ulcers are characteristically linear and may coalesce to produce transverse sinuses with islands of normal mucosa in between, thus giving the characteristic cobblestone appearance.

questions.text: Which artery branches and forms the cystic artery?
questions.solution:
• The cystic artery, a branch of the right hepatic artery, usually arises behind the common hepatic duct.
  • Occasionally, an accessory cystic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery. In 15% of cases the right hepatic artery and/ or the cystic artery crosses in front of the common hepatic duct and the cystic duct.
  • Calot's triangle, or the hepatobiliary triangle, was initially described by Calot as the space bordered by the cystic duct inferiorly, the common hepatic duct medially and the superior border of the cystic artery.
  • This has been modified in contemporary literature to be the area bound superiorly by the inferior surface of the liver, laterally by the cystic duct and the medial border of the gallbladder and medially by the common hepatic duct.
  • It is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within its boundaries and should be identified by surgeons performing a cholecystectomy to avoid damage to the extrahepatic biliary system.

questions.text: Match the following names of health committees in India:
questions.solution:
A) BHORE COMMITTEE,1946

  1. The most comprehensive health policy and plan document ever prepared in India was the 'Health Survey and Development Committee Report' popularly referred to as the Bhore Committee.
  2. This committee was appointed in 1943 with Sir Joseph Bhore as its Chairman.
  3. It made comprehensive recommendations for remodelling of health services in India.

B) MUDALIAR COMMITTEE,1962

  • This committee is known as the 'Health Survey and Planning Committee', headed by Dr. A.L. Mudaliar, was set up in 1959:
    1. To assess the performance in the health sector since the submission of the Bhore Committee report.
    2. To evaluate the progress made in the first 2 plans and
    3. To make recommendations for the future path of development of health services.

C) JUNGALWALLA COMMITTEE,1967

  1. This committee, known as the 'Committee on Integration of Health Services' was set up in 1964 under the chairmanship of Dr. N Jungalwalla, the then Director of National Institute of Health Administration and Education (currently NIHFW).
  2. It was asked to look into various problems related to integration of health services, abolition of private practice by doctors in government services, and the service conditions of Doctors.
  3. The committee defined 'integrated health services' as :-
    • a) A service with a unified approach for all problems instead of a segmented approach for different problems.
    • b) Medical care and public health programmes should be put under charge of a single administrator at all levels of hierarchy.

D)KARTAR SINGH COMMITTEE,1973

  1. This committee, headed by the Additional Secretary of Health and titled the 'Committee on multipurpose workers under Health and Family Planning' was constituted to form a framework for integration of health and medical services at peripheral and supervisory levels.

questions.text: A 22 - Year -old women presents with primary amenorrhea. she has normal secondary sexual characteristics and a normal height. On pelvic Examination, there is a blind ending vaginal pouch. Ultrasound shows absent uterus and normal ovaries. What is the most diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Clinical Presentation suggests a disorder involving congenital absence of the uterus with normal ovarian function, which is characteristic of mayer - Rokitansky- kuster - hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

Option C) Mayer - Rokitansky - Kuster - hauser (MRKH) syndrome :

MRKH syndrome is characterized by congenital absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, with normal external genitalia and normal ovarian function. Patients presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and a blind ending vaginal pouch, as described in this case. This normal ovaries support this diagnosis.

Option A) Turner Syndrome :

Turner Syndrome typically presents with short stature, webbed neck, lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to ovarian dysgenesis (streak ovaries). it does not match this patients normal height

Option B) Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Androgen insensitivity syndrome presents with primary amenorrhea, normal breast development, absent or sparse pubic and axillary hair, and a blind - ending vaginal pouch. However these patients have 46,XY Karyotype with testes (not ovaries), and their condition is related to androgen resistance, leading to female external genitalia despite XY chromosomes.

OPTION D) Kallmann syndrome:

Kallmann syndrome involves primary amenorrhea with lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia. The presence of normal secondary sexual characteristics in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Topic: Disorders of sexual development

choices.text: Low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of 3 consecutive first-trimester miscarriages is evaluated for recurrent pregnancy loss. Her laboratory results show elevated anti-cardiolipin antibodies. What is the most appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of future miscarriages?
questions.solution:
The patient has a history of recurrent pregnancy loss with elevated anti-cardiolipin antibodies, indicating Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), a disorder associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic events and pregnancy complications, including recurrent miscarriages.

OPTION B) Low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin:

This combination is the recommended treatment for women with APS and recurrent pregnancy loss. Low-dose aspirin helps reduce platelet aggregation, while low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) reduces thrombotic events by anticoagulation. This combination has been shown to improve pregnancy outcomes significantly in women with APS.

OPTION A) Low-dose aspirin:

Low-dose aspirin alone may reduce some risk, but it is not as effective as the combination of aspirin and heparin for preventing miscarriage in patients with APS.

OPTION C) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):

IVIG is not routinely used for APS-related pregnancy loss. It may be considered in rare cases, such as those refractory to standard treatment, but it is not the first-line therapy.

OPTION D) Progesterone supplementation:

Progesterone is used for luteal phase support and in some cases of idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss, but it is not specifically indicated for APS-associated pregnancy loss.

questions.text: A 29 years old male presents with complaints of worsening of intense urinary frequency, urgency and small quantity voids. Cystogram image is as below. What is the spot diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retrograde cystography shows a thimble bladder (exceedingly contracted bladder). This is seen in tuberculous cystitis.

  • Secondary to renal tuberculosis.
  • Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone.
  • The earliest evidence is pallor of the mucosa due to submucous oedema.
  • Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.
  • In longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced causing thimble bladder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with Chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. Pain described as squeezing and severe (9/10). Associated symptoms: shortness of breath, nausea, and diaphoresis. ECG: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels: elevated. Microscopic examination is given below. This microscopic change seen after how many days of disease?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms and ECG findings are consistent with STEMI, a type of myocardial infarction.

This myocardial infarction is about 3 to 4 days old.

  • There is an extensive acute inflammatory cell infiltrate, and many neutrophils are undergoing karyorrhexis.
  • The myocardial fibers are undergoing necrosis so that the outlines of them are not well defined.
  • Few cross striations remain, and cell nuclei are no longer visible.
  • The serum troponin would be elevated.

Histological features of MI at different stages, without reperfusion; myofiber waviness (a); interstitial oedema (b); hypereosinophilia and coagulative necrosis of cardiomyocytes (c); heavy granulocyte infiltration with karyorrhexis (d); macrophages and lymphocyte infiltration with early removal of necrotic debris (e); granulation tissue with formation of microvessels (f); fibroblast proliferation and early collagen deposition (g); dense fibrous scar replacing myocyte loss (h). All sections are stained with haematoxylin and eosin

choices.text: High mechanical fragility and high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility and low osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility and high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility and low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Sickle cells have______?
questions.solution:
Low Osmotic Fragility:

  • 1. Abnormal membrane structure: Sickle cells have a more rigid and less flexible membrane due to the presence of hemoglobin S (HbS). This makes them less prone to swelling and bursting in hypotonic solutions.
  • Decreased surface area-to-volume ratio: Sickle cells are more dense and have a smaller surface area-to-volume ratio, making them less susceptible to osmotic stress.
  • Increased cell density: Sickle cells have a higher density due to the polymerization of HbS, which reduces their ability to swell in hypotonic solutions.

High Mechanical Fragility:

  • Repeated sickling and unsickling: Sickle cells undergo repeated cycles of sickling and unsickling, leading to mechanical stress and damage to the cell membrane.
  • Oxidative stress: Sickle cells are more susceptible to oxidative damage due to the presence of HbS, which can lead to membrane damage and increased mechanical fragility.
  • Dehydration: Sickle cells are more prone to dehydration due to the loss of water and ions through the cell membrane, making them more susceptible to mechanical stress.
  • Abnormal cytoskeleton: Sickle cells have an abnormal cytoskeleton, which can lead to changes in cell shape and increased mechanical fragility.
  • These factors contribute to the unique combination of low osmotic fragility and high mechanical fragility in sickle cells, making them more susceptible to hemolysis and other complications.

A 35-year-old male presents with Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), Hematuria, Proteinuria. Serum analysis reveals Positive PR3-ANCA. Renal biopsy shows Necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wegener's granulomatosis, now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), is a rare autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of the small and medium sized blood vessels (vasculitis).

Pathophysiology:

  • Immune-mediated response: GPA is associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), particularly PR3-ANCA (Proteinase 3-ANCA). These antibodies cause neutrophils to damage blood vessels, leading to vasculitis.
  • Granulomatous inflammation: The disease leads to the formation of granulomas, which are localized inflammatory responses involving immune cells. These granulomas can occur in various organs, causing localized tissue necrosis and further complicating blood flow.

Microscopic image showing features characteristic of granulomatosis with polyangiitis - a vasculitis and granulomas with multi-nucleated giant cells.

Clinical Presentation:

  1. Upper respiratory tract:
    • Chronic sinusitis, nasal crusting, and sometimes nasal septal perforation.
    • Saddle nose deformity due to cartilage destruction.
  2. Lungs:
    • Cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain.
    • Pulmonary nodules or cavitating lesions seen on imaging.
  3. Kidneys:
    • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) leading to renal failure.
    • Hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension.
  4. Other systems:
    • Skin: Purpura, ulcers.
    • Eyes: Scleritis, conjunctivitis.
    • Joints: Arthritis.

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a hallmark of GPA.

Option A: MPA: typically associated with MPO-ANCA, not PR3-ANCA. Unlike granulomatosis with polyangiitis, MPA typically lacks granulomatous inflammation but can cause rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

Option C:EGPA: It is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and MPO-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Goodpasture Syndrome: associated with anti-GBM antibodies, not PR3-ANCA.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with Proptosis, Periorbital ecchymosis, Abdominal mass. Biopsy of the abdominal mass reveals neuroblastoma. What is the most likely location of the primary tumor?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from neural crest cells, typically affecting the adrenal glands or sympathetic nervous system in children.

Common Sites:

  • Adrenal glands (most common site)
  • Paraspinal sympathetic chain
  • Cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic ganglia

Clinical Presentation:

  • Abdominal mass: Most common symptom, often painless and firm.
  • Metastatic disease: Bone pain, periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes"), and hepatomegaly.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes: Hypertension, diarrhea, or opsoclonus-myoclonus (dancing eye syndrome).
  • Proptosis and periorbital ecchymosis suggest metastasis to the orbits.

Biomarkers:

  • Elevated urinary catecholamine metabolites (HVA, VMA) are diagnostic markers.
  • Serum markers like neuron-specific enolase (NSE) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) may be elevated.

Pathology:

  • Small, round, blue cells on histology.
  • Homer-Wright rosettes (tumor cells arranged around a neuropil core).

Genetics:

  • N MYC amplification: Associated with poor prognosis and aggressive disease.
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Deletions on chromosome 1p, gain on 17q.

questions.text: What is the investigation depicted below?
questions.solution:
A. This is a Flow Cytometry Result chart which can be displayed by Histogram or dot plot.

It Displays:

  • Cell population distribution
  • Fluorescence intensity (x-axis)
  • Cell count (y-axis)

Key differences between other techniques:

  1. Data representation: Flow cytometry (histograms), FISH (images/tables), IHC (images/tables), PCR (gel images/tables)
  2. Data interpretation: Flow cytometry (cell populations), FISH (gene amplification), IHC (protein expression), PCR (gene expression/mutation)
  3. Quantification: Flow cytometry (fluorescence intensity), FISH (signal intensity), IHC (staining intensity), PCR (Ct values)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with severe Hemophilia A presents with a severe hemorrhage. Which blood component is most appropriate for transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hemophilia A is a genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in Factor VIII, a clotting protein, leading to impaired blood clotting.

  • X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are usually carriers.
  • Mutation in the F8 gene located on the X chromosome, leading to reduced or absent Factor VIII activity.

Clinical Features:

  • Spontaneous bleeding in severe cases.
  • Prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
  • Hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints), leading to joint pain and arthritis.
  • Intramuscular and intracranial hemorrhages in severe cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Prolonged aPTT (activated partial thromboplastin time).
  • Normal PT (prothrombin time) and platelet count.
  • Factor VIII assay to confirm deficiency.

Management:

  • Factor VIII replacement therapy: Recombinant or plasma-derived Factor VIII.
  • Desmopressin (DDAVP): Increases Factor VIII levels in mild cases.
  • Antifibrinolytics (e.g., tranexamic acid) for minor bleeding.
  • Gene therapy (experimental): Emerging treatment for long-term cure.

Incorrect Options:

  1. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) contains factor VIII, but is not as concentrated.
  2. Factor IX concentrate is given to patients with hemophilia B.
  3. Platelet Concentrate is not relevant for Hemophilia A treatment.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Factor VIII is required for Hemophilia A.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient with EDS presents with Recurring joint dislocations, Skin hyperextensibility and Easy bruising. He has gene defect in COL5A1, and COL5A2.

Electron microscopy of skin tissue shows:
1. Abnormal collagen fibril structure
2. Reduced collagen fiber density
3. Increased elastic fiber fragmentation
4. Abnormal fibroblast morphology

What is the most likely EDS subtype?
questions.solution:
Classical Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a genetic connective tissue disorder characterized by skin hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, and tissue fragility.

Inheritance: Autosomal dominant

Cause: Mutations in the COL5A1 or COL5A2 genes, which encode for type V collagen, leading to defective collagen production.

Key Clinical Features:

  • Skin Hyperextensibility: Skin can stretch easily but returns to normal when released.
  • Joint Hypermobility: Unusually flexible joints prone to dislocations and sprains.
  • Fragile Skin: Easy bruising and abnormal scarring (atrophic scars).
  • Poor Wound Healing: Wounds often heal with widened, thin scars.
  • Molluscoid Pseudotumors: Small, soft, fleshy growths over pressure points.

Incorrect Options: B, C and D

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Classical Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a genetic connective tissue disorder characterized by skin hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, and tissue fragility.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used in given image to demonstrate this particular structure of amyloid?
questions.solution:
This is an electron micrograph of amyloid fibrils.

Electron Microscopy (EM) is a gold standard technique to visualize the fibrillar structure of amyloid : Amyloid fibrils appear as straight or curved rigid fibrils with a diameter of 7-10 nm.

Explanation:

Amyloid is an abnormal protein that deposits extracellularly in various tissues and organs, leading to organ dysfunction.

Composition: Made of non-branching fibrils that are approximately 7.5 to 10 nm in diameter, arranged in a β-pleated sheet conformation.


  1. Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining used for histopathology.
  2. Congo red staining gives apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
  3. Thio flavin T fluorescence is a sensitive method for detecting amyloid fibrils in:

1. Histological sections

2. Biofluids (e.g., blood, CSF)

3. Cell cultures

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Amyloid is an abnormal protein that deposits extracellularly in various tissues and organs, leading to organ dysfunction.

Made of non-branching fibrils that are approximately 7.5 to 10 nm in diameter, arranged in a β-pleated sheet conformation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a tumor suppressor gene?
questions.solution:
Tumor suppressor genes are genes that regulate cell growth, division, and repair, and prevent the formation of tumors by inhibiting uncontrolled cell proliferation.

Function: They act as "brakes" on cell division, promote DNA repair, and trigger apoptosis (programmed cell death) when cells are damaged beyond repair.

Types:

  • Gatekeepers: Directly regulate cell growth and apoptosis (e.g., RB, p53).
  • Caretakers: Maintain genome integrity by repairing DNA damage (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2).

Examples:

  • Tp53: Known as the "guardian of the genome", it stops the cell cycle if DNA damage is detected and triggers apoptosis if damage is irreparable.
  • RB (Retinoblastoma protein): Controls cell cycle progression at the G1/S checkpoint.
  • BRCA1/BRCA2: Involved in DNA repair, particularly in repairing double-strand breaks. Mutations in these genes are associated with breast and ovarian cancer.
  • APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli): Regulates cell adhesion and the WNT signaling pathway, mutations lead to colorectal cancer.
  • PTEN: Regulates cell growth and apoptosis; mutations are linked to cancers like breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer.

Mechanism of Inactivation: Tumor suppressor genes typically follow the two-hit hypothesis where both alleles of the gene need to be inactivated (mutated) for tumor formation.

Options A, B & D. TP53, BRCA2, and RB1 are well-known tumor suppressor genes.

C. MYC is an oncogene, which promotes cell proliferation and tumorigenesis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Tumor suppressor genes are genes that regulate cell growth, division, and repair, and prevent the formation of tumors by inhibiting uncontrolled cell proliferation
